A bit of good news; my college has realized they've shafted me too hard and didn't even use the lube(yes I can make everything into a sexual pun) so they're going to actually work towards helping me.  I think the reason why they are going to help me is because they looked at my grades and other than the last two semesters I was not only on the dean's list, but I was really high up on there gpa wise for students.


Also it's probably going to be another year and a half to two years, but the short game I'm working towards is going to like if someone snorted meth and injected shrooms level of crazy.

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54587ee763687210d9610100#post_54587ee763687210d9610100
The problem people have when creating stories is they just mimic what they know already instead of actually think of something interesting.  It's why you see a million COD ripoffs cause when people say they're being "creative" what they really mean is "I'm going to steal this idea and rename it".

People should stop copypasta-ing popular stories and instead think of something new that hasn't been done before.

Inb4 someone steals my game and thinks they're being creative.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545883de6368725d71950200#post_545883de6368725d71950200
Not to put you down, but it can be amazingly difficult to come up with something original. Not just because it runs the risk of alienating your audience if it's too out there, but because there's always that chance that someone, _somewhere_ has already had that same idea. And particularly in regards to video games, originality carries with it a great deal of risk, and most of the time, that risk isn't one financial backers are willing to take.

I'm not saying that any of that is _right_. That's just how it is.
topics.author: 5043cdb47f123b72cc0032d3

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545883de6368725d71950200#post_545883de6368725d71950200
Well you are aware of the phrase "There's no such thing as an original idea" right? I mean you can take a generic idea or plot and make it intersting. Hell the whole plot of One Piece is "Guy gets a crew and goes on a big dumb adventure." Not exactly mind-wracking stuff. But where One Piece shines is in it's characters and world-building. Same with Persona 3. Persona 3's story is the most video game-y story you will ever see but's still interesting to watch the characters deal with the potential armageddon they have to face. What I mean is that there is a difference between being genuinely creative and just over-compensating.
topics.author: 4fde4618945b700aa0002fff

topics.body:
"@Silent_Witness":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545885d46368724430910200#post_545885d46368724430910200
Yeah I know; the paradox here is that it's a risk to do something original but at the same time not doing something original is also a financial risk.  To use a analogy it's like how call of duty is dying hard right now and chances are it's going to send tremors in the games industry when it does go under cause chances are the reaction will be "oh my god!  Generic fps games are a financial risk!"

It's a massive paradox on the one hand if you try something original you're doing a massive risk; on the other hand making a spunkgargleweewee(yes I did just reference yahtzee) game is also a financial risk.
